qas.question: Brain tissue that is living is what color on the outside?
The color of the brain inside is what?
Brains are surrounded by what system of tissues?
Meninges separate what structure from the brain?
The blood-brain barrier is made up of what?

answers.text: cells in the blood vessel walls

context: The brains of vertebrates are made of very soft tissue. Living brain tissue is <a0_0>pinkish<a0_0/> on the outside and mostly <a1_0>white<a1_0/> on the inside, with subtle variations in color. Vertebrate brains are surrounded by a system of connective tissue membranes called <a2_0>meninges<a2_0/> that separate <a3_0>the skull<a3_0/> from the brain. Blood vessels enter the central nervous system through holes in the meningeal layers. The <a4_0>cells in the blood vessel walls<a4_0/> are joined tightly to one another, forming the blood–brain barrier, which blocks the passage of many toxins and pathogens (though at the same time blocking antibodies and some drugs, thereby presenting special challenges in treatment of diseases of the brain).
